inedi
Class OftpserverAcceptFileEvent

java.lang.Object
  java.util.EventObject
      inedi.OftpserverAcceptFileEvent
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public class OftpserverAcceptFileEvent
extends java.util.EventObject

Fired when the client sends a file.

This event controls the behavior when the client sends a file to the server.

Overwrite is false by default, but may be set to true to overwrite existing files on disk.

Filename will be populated with the full path and filename that will be written. It may be changed within this event to specify a new location. The Filename is determined by combining the path specified in DownloadDirectory and the name received from the client.

Accept is true by default, and must be set to false in order to reject the file.

VirtualFileName holds the name of the file being received.

VirtualFileDate holds the date associated with the file in the format specified by VirtualFileDateFormat . The default value is "MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss".

Originator identifies the sender (SFID) code in the send file request.

Destination identifies the receiver (SFID) code in the send file request. If the file was intended for this server this will match the value in ServerSFIDCode

ErrorCode controls the error returned to the client when Accept is set to False. If this is not set the bean will use a value of 99 to indicate a general error. ErrorDescription may also be set to include an error message. If this is not set the bean will automatically include an error message based on the ErrorCode specified. Common error codes and their corresponding error messages are listed below.

ErrorCode\011
ErrorMessage
1\011\011\011\011\011
Invalid filename.
2\011\011\011\011\011
Invalid destination.
3\011\011\011\011\011
Invalid origin.
4\011\011\011\011\011
Storage record format not supported.
5\011\011\011\011\011
Maximum record length not supported.
6\011\011\011\011\011
File size is too big.
10\011\011\011\011
Invalid record count.
11\011\011\011\011
Invalid byte count.
12\011\011\011\011
Access method failure.
13\011\011\011\011
Duplicate file.
14\011\011\011\011
File direction refused.
15\011\011\011\011
Cipher suite not supported.
16\011\011\011\011
Encrypted file not allowed.
17\011\011\011\011
Unencrypted file not allowed.
18\011\011\011\011
Compression not allowed.
19\011\011\011\011
Signed file not allowed.
20\011\011\011\011
Unsigned file not allowed.
99\011\011\011\011
Unspecified reason.
